# Read in data
```{r Read in data}
dat_initial <- readRDS(file = "../data_cleaned/final_dat_merged_exclusions_2022-10-04.rds")
dim(dat_initial)
colnames(dat_initial)

dat_initial %>% 
     group_by(ID) %>%
     filter(n()>1)

length(unique(dat_initial$ID))
```

# Read in IBD data
```{r read in IBD data}
# RAMP
ramp_IBD <- readRDS(paste0(filepath_raw_latest_freeze, "ramp/health_ramp.rds"))

ramp_IBD <- ramp_IBD %>%
  drop_na(`Login ID`) %>% # Drop NAs
  remove_duplicates("Login ID") %>% # Remove duplicates based on ID
  select(ID = `Login ID`,
         IBD_crohns = health.inflammatory_bowel_disease_crohns,
         IBS = health.irritable_bowel_syndrome_)

# NBR
nbr_IBD <- readRDS(paste0(filepath_raw_latest_freeze, "coping_nbr/health_coping_nbr.rds"))

nbr_IBD <- nbr_IBD %>%
   drop_na(subjectid) %>% # Drop NAs
  remove_duplicates("subjectid") %>% # Remove duplicates based on ID
 select(ID = subjectid,
         IBD_crohns = health.inflammatory_bowel_disease_crohns,
         IBS = health.irritable_bowel_syndrome_)

# EDGI
edgi_IBD <- readRDS(paste0(filepath_raw_latest_freeze, "coping_edgi/health_coping_edgi.rds"))

edgi_IBD <- edgi_IBD %>%
  drop_na(externalDataReference) %>% # Drop NAs
  remove_duplicates("externalDataReference") %>% # Remove duplicates based on ID
  select(ID = externalDataReference,
         IBD_crohns = health.inflammatory_bowel_disease_crohns,
         IBS = health.irritable_bowel_syndrome_)

# GLAD
glad_IBD <- readRDS(paste0(filepath_raw_latest_freeze, "coping_glad/health_coping_glad.rds"))

glad_IBD <- glad_IBD %>%
  drop_na(externalDataReference) %>% # Drop NAs
  remove_duplicates("externalDataReference") %>% # Remove duplicates based on ID
 select(ID = externalDataReference,
         IBD_crohns = health.inflammatory_bowel_disease_crohns,
         IBS = health.irritable_bowel_syndrome_)
```

# Bind IBD/IBS data
```{r bind IBD data}
IBD_crohns_IBS <- ramp_IBD %>%
  bind_rows(nbr_IBD,
            edgi_IBD,
            glad_IBD)

length(unique(IBD_crohns_IBS$ID))
```

# Merge IBD/IBS/Crohns data with dat
```{r merge IBS data with dat}
dat <- dplyr::left_join(dat_initial,
                        IBD_crohns_IBS,
                        by = "ID")
```

# Exclude those with IBD or from an IBD cohort
```{r exclude IDB}
# Exclude IBD cohort
dat <- dat %>%
  filter((sample == "GLAD" |
           sample == "EDGI" |
           sample == "RAMP") |
         cohort != "IBD")

# Check
dat %>%
  freq(cohort)

# Exclude those with IBD / Crohns
dat <- dat %>% 
  filter(IBD_crohns == 0 )


# check
dat %>%
  freq(IBD_crohns)
```

```{r change panworry to factor}
dat <- dat %>%
  mutate(panworry_factor =
           case_when(panworry_total_score > -1 &
                       panworry_total_score <= 20 ~ "0-20",
             
                     panworry_total_score > 20 &
                       panworry_total_score <= 40 ~ "21-40",
                     
                     panworry_total_score > 40 &
                      panworry_total_score <= 60 ~ "41-60",
                     
                      panworry_total_score > 60 &
                      panworry_total_score <= 80 ~ "61-80"
                     )
         )
```

### Re-ordering variables / converting to factors
First, re-order all variables to get desired reference category for plotting - put largest category as reference
Age
```{r Re-order age levels}
dat <- dat %>%
  mutate(age_category_COVID_baseline = factor(age_category_COVID_baseline,
                       levels = c("46-55", # Mid-life
                                   "16-25",
                                  "26-35",
                                  "36-45",
                                  "56-65", 
                                   "66-70",
                                   "71+")
                       )
         )

# Check
dat %>%
  freq(age_category_COVID_baseline)
```

Race
```{r Re-order race levels}
dat <- dat %>%
  mutate(race_binary = factor(race_binary,
                       levels = c("White", # Largest category
                                  "Racially minoritised"
                                  )))
dat %>%
  freq(race_binary)
```

Psychiatric disorder
```{r  Re-order psych disorder levels}
# First recode to "Yes" and "No"
dat <- dat %>%
  mutate(psych_disorder_factor =
           case_when(
            mental_health_diagnosis == "Psychiatric disorder" ~ "Yes", 
            mental_health_diagnosis == "No psychiatric disorder" ~ "No")
  )

# Check 
dat %>%
  freq(psych_disorder_factor)

# Then change order
dat <- dat %>%
  mutate(psych_disorder_factor = factor(psych_disorder_factor,
                       levels = c( "No", # Ref category
                                  "Yes"
                                  )))

# Check again
dat %>%
  freq(psych_disorder_factor)
```

Employment
```{r Re-order employment levels}
dat <- dat%>%
  mutate(paid_employment_key_worker = factor(paid_employment_key_worker,
                       levels = c("Paid employment",  
                                  "Key worker",
                                  "Not paid employment",
                                  "Retired",
                                  "Student"
                                  )
                       )
         )

# Check
dat %>%
  freq(paid_employment_key_worker)
```

# REGRESSION MODELS
## Binge eating
Age, gender, race, education, psych disorder, key worker/employment status, vulnerable group member, pandemic worry, positive COVID test, loss of loved one, change in main eco activity, change in living situation

Pandemic worry: If you include a continuous predictor in your logistic regression, the exponentiated coefficient represents the odds ratio for one unit change in the predictor. Often, one unit isn't meaningful and you want the odds ratio for, say, 10 units. To calculate this, just exponentiate the coefficient multiplied by 10: ùëÇùëÖ10=exp(ùõΩ‚ãÖ10). 
```{r Binge eating age model}
# Reference category
dat <- within(dat,
              age_category_COVID_baseline <- relevel(age_category_COVID_baseline,
                                                     ref = "46-55"))

model_age <- glm(NEW_binge_eating_pandemic ~  
                 age_category_COVID_baseline,
                 data = dat,
                 family = "binomial"
              )

binge_eating_age <- tidy(model_age,
     conf.int=TRUE,
     exponentiate=TRUE)

fitted(model_age) %>% 
  length()

binge_eating_age
```

```{r plot binge eating regression results}
    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = 1),

    geom_point(data=df_sig,
```

### Correlation with main analysis 
